Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Fitting Ebola multi-type branching process models to data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main goal of the project is to provide the scientific community with a set of quantitative modeling tools that will assist in the real-time identification of factors contributing most to the ongoing spread of Ebola in Africa, and that will allow straightforward testing of plausible intervention strategies. This will be done by developing branching process models of the spread of Ebola that connect to available data sources, and that allow for changes in human behavior as well as incorporate realistic scenarios aimed at mitigating transmission. Estimates of the key transmission rates and associated measures of uncertainty will allow for improved precision in forecasting under a range of scenarios.

While multi-type branching process models are an ideal way to capture key heterogeneities in transmission, and can readily include the dynamic landscape associated with serious disease threats unfolding in real time, their potential is maximized only when we develop techniques to interface them with data. This is a two-way communication in which existing data allows estimation of critical process rates and probabilities, and in addition, the accurately parameterized models allow forecasting. For the ongoing Ebola outbreak in West Africa, the utility of both wings of this workflow have important implications. More broadly, multi-type branching process models have wide applicability to emerging infectious disease threats. Improving fitting techniques for such models fills a knowledge gap regarding the connection between a flexible modeling framework and available data sources. By identifying simple, key heterogeneities in transmission, the modeling approach transcends purpose-built models that are not easily extended to other systems. Models and associated fitting procedures for the analysis of data related to the Ebola disease will be relevant also for future emerging disease threats.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project applied mathematical modeling techniques (mechanistic and statistical) to understand and predict the spread of Ebola virus in West Africa.

In line with original project goals - a primary focus was interfacing models and data. This has resulted in three manuscripts that are in review:

(1) Schmidt, J.P., Park, A.W., Kramer, A.M., Han, B.A., Alexander, L.W. & Drake, J.M. Spatiotemporal fluctuations and triggers of Ebola virus spillover. Emerging Infectious Diseases

(2) Kramer, A.M., Pulliam, J.T., Alexander, L.W., Park, A.W., Rohani, P. & Drake, J.M. Spatial spread of the West Africa Ebola epidemic. Proceedings Royal Society B

 

(3) Vinson, J.E, Drake, J.M., Rohani, P. & Park, A.W. The potential for sexual transmission to compromise control of Ebola virus outbreaks. Biology Letters

There is an additional manuscript in preparation:

(4) Working title: Challenges of fitting branching process models to data with special reference to Ebola. 

Subproject 1 identified candidate spatiotemporal triggers for Ebola virus outbreaks using data in Africa from 1970s to present day. The outbreak triggers included transition times between wet and dry seasons as well as high and low (but not intermedidate) human population sizes. Methodologically, the research uncovoered the importance of using ensemble machine learning methods (particularly aggregated bootstrapping, or bagging) to avoid overfitting. 

Subproject 2 provided the first rigorous demonstration of which factors contribute most to explaining spatial spread patterns of the recent outbreak in West Africa. These include district population size, inter-district distance and the national border closures. Methdologically, the project developed a generalized gravity model framework to admit explicit likelihood functions that encode mechanistic descriptions of transmission potential. The study identified that individual movement pattern data based on moblie (cell) phone data was a poor predictor of epidemic development in space. 

Subproject 3 was unantcipated, but was a natural direction to pursue based on emerging data on the potential for sexual transmission of Ebola. The study included data analysis of a convenience sample of convalescent male survivors of Ebola to determine the distribution of times spent in a sexually infectious state. This was integrated into a compartment modeling framework with direct and sexual transmission to assess the extent to which sexual transmission may compromise conrol efforts targetting only direct transmission. 

Subproject 4 makes use of particle filtering to infer mechanism, process rates and probabilities of partially observed markov processes. This includes a measurement model capturing phenomena such as under-reporting. Some technical obstacles need to be overcome to bring this to publication, and this remains an active goal.
